none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, August 26, 1872
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, August 26, 1872
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 13 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A personal letter from William A. Alexander to his friend Louis L. McInnis, written from Kosciusko, Mississippi on August 26, 1872, during summer vacation from the University of Mississippi. Alexander discusses his academic achievements in Greek and Mathematics, his friend's examination results, and his limited scholarly pursuits during vacation, expressing eagerness to return to university for his sophomore year. The letter provides commentary on the social lives and activities of fellow students, local development in Kosciusko, and includes encouragement for McInnis to prepare physically for the demanding sophomore year ahead.

body.value:
Kosciusko, Miss, August 26th:-72

Dear Friend Louis..

I received a letter
from Ellie Bingham. this evening.
in which he stated that you were
sojourning in Forest     Hoping
that this may find you still
there, and enjoying good health, I
will indulge myself for a little
while in writing to you.

This leaves me well. The
community, as a general thing, enjoys
good health.

I have not the least doubt, but
that you properly attended to our books.

Well, my Greek and Mathematics
came out very satisfactorily to me,
being 97 & 100, respectively.

I hope you did well in your ex-
amination on Saturday, the 29th & that

Okay, it looks like this is a letter, and I need to transcribe it. The guidelines say to preserve the original format, so I'll need to pay close attention to line breaks and indentation. The HTML tags are a constraint, so I'll keep those in mind. 1. **Image Analysis & Deconstruction:** I'm starting by taking a look at the image and figuring out what I see. First, the header: "Kosciusko, Miss, August 26th-72". I see "Miss" - that's Mississippi, probably. The date is a bit tricky, but it's clearly August and then `26th-72`. Okay, the salutation: "Dear Friend Louis..". Simple enough. The body looks like separate paragraphs. I'll need to figure out the line breaks. * Okay, paragraph 1: I've got "I received a letter... Ellie Bingham... sojourning in Forest..." Got it. * Paragraph 2: "...This leaves me well... the community... good health." Straightforward. * Paragraph 3: "...I have not the least doubt... books." Alright. * Paragraph 4: "...Well, my Greek and Mathematics... 97 & 100..." Nice. * Paragraph 5: "...I hope you did well in your ex- ... amination...". The sentence gets cut off at the bottom. 2. **Detailed Analysis & Verification:** Now, I'm going to zoom in and double-check everything. Let's start from the top. "Kosciusko, Miss," - the "ss" looks like a long s and short s. "August 26th-72". The "th" is superscript. The "72" is small. "Ellie Bingham". The "E" looks a little loopy but it's most likely an "E". The second name is "Bingham". "sojourning in Forest" - "Forest" is capitalized. Good to note. "Hoping" - also capitalized. "indulge myself" - clear. "This leaves me well." - clear. "The community, as a general thing, enjoys good health." Clear. "I have not the least doubt, but that you properly attended to our books." Clear. "Well, my Greek and Mathematics came out very satisfactorily to me, being 97 & 100, respectively." Got it. The line cut-off: "I hope you did well in your ex-". The hyphen is there. "amination on Saturday, the 29th & that" - Superscript "th", and the ampersand "&". 3. **Formatting and Structure:** Now, according to the guidelines, I need to use the `p` tags to maintain paragraphs, and `br` for line breaks. I have a format I need to follow. I will create paragraphs based on the indentation. It looks like "Dear Friend Louis.." is its own paragraph. I'll make sure to preserve all line breaks. 4. **Drafting the Transcription:** I'll use the analysis from the previous step and write it out. * Okay, here's what I have: ```html

Kosciusko, Miss, August 26th-72

Dear Friend Louis..

I received a letter
from Ellie Bingham this evening,
in which he stated that you were
sojourning in Forest Hoping
that this may find you still
there, and enjoying good health, I
will indulge myself for a little
while in writing to you.

This leaves me well. The
community, as a general thing, enjoys
good health.

I have not the least doubt, but
that you properly attended to our books.

Well, my Greek and Mathematics
came out very satisfactorily to me,
being 97 & 100, respectively.

I hope you did well in your ex-
amination on Saturday, the 29th & that

``` 5. **Refinement:** Now, time for the fine-tooth comb.

your report gave you satisfaction.
    I have heard from Hays once or
twice. At last accounts, he was in
St. Paul, Minn. and expected to be here about
the 1st of Sept.
    Since I have gotten home, I have not
done anything in particular. I hunted
and fished a little when I first got
home, but soon found out that it did
not pay. I have not studied any,
either. I picked up my G. Prose and
wrote off two sentences of the 8th exercise;
I took up a Homer and read the 1st
line, which is the amount of my study-
-ing during vacation. At the present,
    I am reading Macauley.
    I have begun to wish vacation to be
over with, for I want to get back to
the University. There will be no
new fellows from this County who will go
back to Oxford this coming term,
though there will be several next term.
    I understand that J.L. Dodd has
been offered one of the $500 tutorships.

**Image Transcription: My Thought Process** Alright, let's get to work. The task is to transcribe this handwritten letter, and I need to be precise. I’ll go through it line by line, paying close attention to every detail, especially since the guidelines say to preserve line breaks, spelling, punctuation, capitalization and any original quirks in the writing. The style suggests it's from the late 19th or early 20th century. I'm noting mentions of places like St. Paul, Minn., and names like Macaulay, Homer, and Oxford, which helps frame the context. I have to remember allowable HTML tags are `a, b, br, i, img, p, small, span, sub, sup`. First line: "your report gave you satisfaction." Seems straightforward. Next line... Line 2, "I have heard from Hays once or..." Now the fun begins! Is it Hays, Hayes, or maybe something else? I'm examining this name closely, looking at the letter formations to decode it. At first, it looks like "Hayo". I have to consider the context of the word and the general context of the words in the sentence. Given that this is a name, "Hays" or "Hayes" seems more plausible, but that final letter is a bit looped. I have to compare it to other 's' letters in the text, to the 'o's, the 'y' and look at the "fellows". Ok, the 'y' looks like a 'y', the looped 's' is likely an 's'. So, tentatively "Hays." Line 3, "twice. At last accounts, he was in..." The first part sounds like the end of the previous sentence. Period. Then the new sentence begins with "At". Okay, now into the letter's body: Line 6, "Since I have gotten home, I have not..." I notice the implied paragraph, the indentation. I'll maintain that. Moving on, I'm noting possible Greek studies, “G. Prose” (that’s likely Greek Prose), and using proper superscript `` tags for the "1st", "8th" lines. Line 15 "-ing during vacation. At the present,"... The end of line 15 is tricky. It seems that "I am reading Macauley" continues in the next line, but visually starts on a new line and indented! The layout is a little ambiguous here, so I'll follow the formatting as closely as possible. Line 16, "I am reading Macauley" The name looks unusual. Is it Macauley or Macaulay? Checking the handwriting, it appears to be Macauley. I double-check "Macaulay" is often misspelled. The handwriting *does* look like "Macauley" but it's probably Macaulay. Let's stick with Macaulay. Yes, standard. The "J.L. Dodd" looks straightforward and I have to choose. J.L. seems right, and Dodd has a clear 'd'. Looking at the image, I have to be sure. It could be J.S. so I check again. No, L. Like "Last" earlier. The loop goes up, then down, then crossed by the line. So L is clear. I have to carefully assess if "County" is being used, or if it is "Country". Checking, no the letters are County. "County". Now I am ready to transcribe:

your report gave you satisfaction.
    I have heard from Hays once or
twice. At last accounts, he was in
St. Paul, Minn. and expected to be here about
the 1st of Sept.
    Since I have gotten home, I have not
done anything in particular. I hunted
and fished a little when I first got
home, but soon found out that it did
not pay. I have not studied any,
either. I picked up my G. Prose and
wrote off two sentences of the 8th exercise;
I took up a Homer and read the 1st
line, which is the amount of my study-
-ing during vacation. At the present,
    I am reading Macauley.
    I have begun to wish vacation to be
over with, for I want to get back to
the University. There will be no
new fellows from

[Margin: T.B.]
at Oxford. I do not know whether he
will accept. or not, as he is not here,
but absent in Kentucky. John
Thompson is up here spending the summer.
He has turned out his whiskers, and
I reckon that means his going to marry.
Kosciusko is improving at this time.
Several dwellings and stores are in the
course of erection, and a good many more
will be begun, when ever the lumber can
be obtained.
Bingham writes to me that he sees
Richmond frequently. I suppose he is
in Newton. I hope that he will return
to O & take up his old quarters. Give
him my kindest regards when you
see him. If you see any fellow
proposing to go to Oxford, whom you
would take for a real good fellow. do you
just inform me, for I want to set (on)
him. I hope that our
Sophomore year will pass off as pleasantly
as the departed Fresh. & that we will
all sustain ourselves well, both as a
[Margin: My father is here with me & tells me to leave the Un[?]]

**Transcription Process Deep Dive**

Okay, here's how I approached this transcription task. First, I locked into the requirements: a professional transcription, preserving everything – spelling, punctuation, even the line breaks – and using HTML markup where necessary. No chitchat, just the text.

The image presented a handwritten letter, that was clear enough for the task. The initial scan revealed text in the main body, and a vertical text strip in the left margin. I recognized the handwriting as typical 19th-century cursive.

Now, the methodical transcription began: each line, carefully dissected. Uncertainty gets a `[?]`, and I meticulously maintained the original formatting. I treated each line of text and each break, as written. I did several passes, and often went back to refine the transcription of an uncertain word. I was extremely careful to render precisely what was seen.

The main body transcription was fairly straightforward. I had to look closely at details like the "O" in "to O" (Oxford?) and the "set (on)". The ampersand also, the punctuation after the sentence, after "fellow". My understanding of idiom and word placement helped interpret the handwriting, but I transcribed as I saw it. I wanted to balance precision and legibility.

Then came the margin text. This was the trickier part. It’s written vertically (bottom to top), the text starts near the end of the image. The phrase “My father is here with me” became the key. I carefully analyzed the last word which was unclear. At first, I went with `[?]` to be accurate. Then, I looked at "My father...tells me to leave the...". Contextually, "open" made sense. But I saw the *letters* on the page. I took into account the box-like structure and "T.B." at the very top of the page. Then I went back to re-analyze, to accurately transcribe what I saw. I went with "Un[?]" as the best rendering of the visual.

Finally, I formatted the output, placing the margin text at the beginning or end – it’s a side note. The final formatting decision was to place it at the end, at the most appropriate place to avoid breaking the flow.

Precision, that’s my job. The output reflects that.

class and personally.          I write to you
at Forest hoping that you are still there,
and having a fine time.          But should
you leave ere this reaches you.       I guess
it will merely have to go to the Defact Letter
Office.          Stir around and get as
fat and strong as possible before Oct., in
order that the laborious Soph. year may not
be too much for you.          Be sure to write
to me .

As ever. Your true & affectionate friend
                                Wm A Alexander,

L. L. McInnis,
          Forest,
               Miss.

**Analysis and Transcription of Handwritten Letter** Okay, here's the deal. I've got this handwritten letter, and my task is to transcribe it *exactly* as it is, while keeping in mind some HTML formatting restrictions. No extra chat, just the text. The goal is accuracy, and that means capturing every stroke, even the quirks. First, I'm analyzing the provided instructions. I need to handle all the unusual elements, like an archaic "ere," and abbreviations, while staying true to the format of the original. Now, I'm giving the image a good once-over. It's a cursive letter on lined paper. The handwriting is pretty clear, but, it's old and there are going to be those oddities common to older documents. It looks like it's the end of the letter. I can see the closing, the signature, and an address. Okay, let's dive into this line by line. *Line 1:* "class and personally. I write to you." "Class" is fine. "personally." - period. And then there's a huge gap before "I". The writer definitely intended that space. *Line 2:* "at Forest hoping that you are still there," Forest is capitalized. And I see a comma at the end there. *Line 3:* "and having a fine time. But should". The period is faint, but there's a capital "B". *Line 4:* "you leave ere this reaches you. I guess". "Ere" is clear and has a period. And "I guess", is a little messy, but I can read it. *Line 5:* "it will merely have to go to the Defact Letter" - Now, here's where it gets interesting. "Dead Letter Office" is the idiom, but that word. It looks like "Defact". I'm looking at it hard, really hard, and even when I squint, I see "Defact." D-e-f-a-c-t, even if it might be a weird "Dead". I'm really looking at the image here, and yes it is D-e-f-a-c-t. And I need to transcribe what I *see*. *Line 6:* "Office. Stir around and get as". Okay, comma after "Office". "Stir" is capitalized. *Line 7:* "fat and strong as possible before Oct., in". "Oct." abbreviation, and a comma. *Line 8:* "order that the laborious Soph. year may not". "Soph" is capitalized, abbreviation for Sophomore, I suppose. *Line 9:* "be too much for you. Be sure to write". Period at the end. The "to" is a bit squashed, but "Be sure to write" is the sentence. *Line 10:* "to me." Period. *Line 11 (Closing):* "As ever. Your true & affectionate friend". Looks like a period. And an ampersand. *Signature:* "Wm A Alexander," Abbreviation of William, and then the last name. *Addressee (Bottom Left):* "L. L. McInnis," Initials and surname. "Forest," place name. Then, "Miss." - This abbreviation, as in Mississippi. The last letter, the double "s", it's very distinct and it looks like "Mifs." I think, with the old style "s", or a long "s". I need to follow instructions and record what is visible. I am checking the structure of the document: body text, closing, signature, and then the addressee. The body text will be a single paragraph. Your true & affectionate friend

Envelope was stationery of: Office of County Superintendent of Education, Attala County, Kosciusko, Miss.
postmarked Forest, Miss, 8/30/72 - stamped "Missent and Forwarded" -- addressed to Forest, but
Forwarded on to Newton Miss.

[Margin: checked]

Kosciusko, Miss, August 26th, 72.

Dear Friend Louis.

I received a letter from Ellie Bingham this evening,
in which he stated that you were sojourning in Forest. Hoping that this may
find you still there, and enjoying good health, I will indulge myself for a
little while in writing to you.

This leaves me well. The community, as a general thing, enjoys good health.

I have not the least doubt, but that you properly attended to our books.

Well, my Greek and Mathematics came out very satisfactorily to me, be-
ing 97 and 100, respectively.

I hope you did well in your examination on Saturday, the 29th, & that your re-
port gave you satisfaction.

I have heard from Hays once or twice. At last accounts, he was in St.
Paul, Minn. and expected to be here about the 1st of Sept.

Since I have gotten home, I have not done anything in particular. I
hunted and fished a little when I first got home, but soon found out that it
did not pay. I have not studied any, either. I picked up my G. Prose and wrote
off two sentences of the 8th exercise; I took up a Homer and read the 1st line,
which is the amount of my studying during vacation. At the present, I am
reading Macauley.

I have begun to wish vacation to be over with, for I want to get back to
the University. There will be no new fellows from this County who will go
back to Oxford this coming term, though there will be several next term.

**The Transcription Process: A Thoughtful Reconstruction** Okay, so I'm looking at this image, and my primary goal is a faithful transcription of this document. It looks like a personal letter, quite possibly from the late 19th or early 20th century, given the style of the typewriter and the handwriting. My initial assessment is that the document's structure is a combination of handwritten annotations and a typed body. My priority here, and I cannot stress this enough, is absolute accuracy. I have to reproduce the text exactly as it appears, even the idiosyncrasies. I've carefully examined the handwritten top section. I've noted the content of this seemingly envelope-related note, which appears to describe the mailing information. "Envelope was stationery of: Office of County Superintendent of Education, Attala County, Kosciusko, Miss." Then, "postmarked Forest, Miss, 8/30/72 - stamped 'Missent and Forwarded' -- addressed to Forest, but" and finally, "Forwarded on to Newton Miss." I've captured the punctuation, and even those little marks that look like imperfections from the stamp. The "8/30/72" date looks clear. In addition, there is a pencil marking on the left side: "checked". I've confirmed that the date line is positioned at the right margin. The format "Kosciusko, Miss, August 26th, 72." is clear. Then we have the salutation "Dear Friend Louis." Now I turn to the body of the letter. I need to reproduce the typed text exactly, preserving line breaks, indentations, and any unusual spacing. This is the core of this task. I see distinct paragraphs and those visual line breaks must be maintained for accurate representation. * "I received a letter from Ellie Bingham this evening,

ing 97 and 100, respectively." * "I hope you did well in your examination on Saturday, the 29th, & that your re-
port gave you satisfaction." * "I have heard from Hays once or twice. At last accounts, he was in St.

The aim is to make the content accessible while retaining the original document's integrity. It is important to transcribe and format with meticulous care and attention to detail.

L

[Margin: My father's brother who had to
leave the Univ. with T.B.
[written in
red
pencil
later]]

I understand that J. L. Dodd has been offered one of the $500 tutorships
at Oxford. I do not know whether he will accept or not, as he is not here,
but absent in Kentucky. John Thompson is up here spending the summer.

He has turned out his whiskers, and I reckon that means he's going to marry.
Kosciusko is improving at this time. Several dwellings and stores are
in the course of erection, and a good many more will be begun, when ever the
lumber can be obtained.

Bingham writes to me that he sees Richmond frequently. I suppose he is
in Newton. I hope that he will return to O. & take up his old quarters. Give
him my kindest regards when you see him. If you see any fellow proposing to
go to Oxford, whom you would take for a real good fellow, do you just inform
me, for I want to set (on) him. I hope that our Sophomore year will pass off
as pleasantly as the departed Fresh. & that we will all sustain ourselves well,
both as a class and personally. I write to you at Forest hoping that you are
still there, and having a fine time. But should you leave ere this reaches
you, I guess it will merely have to go to the Dead Letter Office. Stir a-
round and get as fat and strong as possible before Oct., in order that the
laborious Soph. year may not be too much for you. Be sure & write to me.

As ever your true & affectionate friend
Wm. A. Alexander,

L. L. McInnis,
Forest,
Miss.

**My Transcription Strategy for this Typed Document** Alright, let's break this down. My goal is to create a faithful transcription of this typed document, considering all the nuances. First, I analyzed the image. It’s a typed letter, and right away, I notice corrections and marginalia. Specifically, the "J. S. Dodd" line has a handwritten 'L' above the typed 'S' with a slash through the 'S', which signals a clear correction. I will have to decide how to handle the "L" correction. There's also some underlined text – "Richmond", "set (on)", and "Dead Letter Office" – indicating emphasis, and a vertical handwritten margin note. I see a faint pencil note below the vertical text. Now, I'll strategize the transcription. The guidelines are clear: capture everything. I'll read the main text and insert the marginalia where it makes sense. The key is to insert the annotations logically, noting the vertical margin note at the start. Since there is a clear intention to correct "J. S. Dodd" to "J. L. Dodd", I will proceed with that corrected version of the name. If the 'L' hadn't been so distinct, I might have given different weight. But this is the final intention, given the clear handwritten insertion. I'll preserve all line breaks. The underline will be represented by *italics*. Next, I need to transcribe the content meticulously. I see the main body concerns university matters, social gossip, and local news from Kosciusko. I must ensure the formatting reflects the original, including the addressee and closing. I've examined the margin note and identified it as "My father's brother who had to leave the Univ. with T.B." with a handwritten annotation below "[written in red pencil later]". The vertical text is in ink (black) and the note below is in pencil (faint), perhaps red pencil? That's what it looks like, and the note itself says "red pencil". I will transcribe it all, and it should be first. I will use `

` tags for paragraphs. Also, I will render the marginal notes with `[Margin: ...]` or `` where appropriate. For underlined text, I will use `` tags as underlines are rendered with italics. I will also transcribe that lone typed "L" at the top as a stand-alone line. As a final step, I will re-read and double-check to be sure I've been completely faithful to the original, including the abbreviations and the punctuation. I am ready.
